section.text: Thank you. Yes, I was hoping you could just talk a little bit about kind of the enterprise and campus strategy. Obviously, you guys have been growing pretty well there. If you could kind of update the $400 million bogey for the year? And you've mentioned [Technical Issues]
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Tim Long", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "e598413f-e0bb-4237-8c88-832f98448da4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Barclays"}

section.text: We lost him. Your audio, you're sounding muffled. Why don't -- I think I'll interpret your question, Tim, even though I only heard half of it, which is what is your status on campus and enterprise strategy, and how are you doing the $400 million target?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "e93f52bf-83b4-44bf-b2dc-82678730422e", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Obviously, we will get back to you when we have completed the year. But at this point, we would say that the strength of our campus business from an order respective is very strong and [Technical Issues] $400 million. We are very supply constrained. So we're not yet sure if we will hit a $400 million from a revenue and shipment perspective.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "e93f52bf-83b4-44bf-b2dc-82678730422e", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: I'm sorry, if you could just touch on the wireless LAN contribution. It sounds like that's doing a little bit better now. Sorry about that. I was muffled a little.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Tim Long", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "239beddb-a535-481f-a004-f02c00275ca8", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Barclays"}

section.text: Yes. No, we are very pleased with our wireless LAN contribution. If you think back, we acquired Mojo Networks in 2018, late 2018, early 2019, and it was a very small single-digit business. And we expect the wireless LAN contribution to become a triple-digit business next year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "34e067ae-73e1-4e4d-8e3d-21dbd6cc713e", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thank you, Tim.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Stine", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "4c641825-5df5-47d5-aad8-fa79112506f7", "speaker_title": "Director, Investor Relations at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Great. Thank you very much. Spectacular results for the quarter, for the year, in fact of the results last year. And I guess the question really boils down to are we going to see a reversion to more normalized growth? And if that happens, does that bring the margins back into the 37% range, and have we set ourselves up against extremely difficult comps as we go into 2023? How do we think about the mechanics of where we are? Alternatively, clearly, supply constraints persist, you sound more constrained than you had earlier, and that would imply to me that at least for the first half of next year or even longer, you might still be in the strong growth trajectory. Can you just address how we should be thinking about the environment as we move forward? Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Alex Henderson", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "ee9a2e9a-f3a2-4c92-af07-2dac8824ac19", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Needham"}

section.text: Alex, thank you for the kind words, and I'll tee it up and certainly let Ita speak to some of the details you are asking about. First of all, I just want to say I'm very proud of the team for executing. As you know, we came into the year expecting 30% growth. And here we are telling you it's going to be 45%. So a huge contribution from Anshul and the team, not only on the Cloud Titans, but all on the enterprise and rest of the cloud business, as we call it led by Anshul and Ashwin. A lot to be proud of, especially as the numbers get larger.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "c8407d3e-09f6-41df-87d0-3a8b3ba7c283", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: So as you think about the numbers getting larger, it's going to be difficult to sustain 45% growth every year. I'd love to have it. But as you know, Arista is a volatile business, and you have to think of us across a three- to five-year CAGR, not just on an annual basis. So I still think we have a large TAM. We're going to do very well. But with the looming uncertainty of recession and capex spend, etc., it's definitely difficult to predict beyond a year. Having said that, I think, as I said before, we're having one of our best ever years in 2022. And even though the comps will be difficult, we feel confident that if supply chain gives us some relief, we can do well in 2023 as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "c8407d3e-09f6-41df-87d0-3a8b3ba7c283", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Ita, would you like to add?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "c8407d3e-09f6-41df-87d0-3a8b3ba7c283", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Yes, I think, Alex, if you go back to the business model, obviously, the gross margin kind of variability that we see that's kind of inherent to the business model is to do with the mix of the business, right? And that kind of works very nicely when you see accelerated cloud, you see that flow through to the operating margin line even though it might be impacting the gross margin in that time period, right?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "9adf2a4b-405b-41d8-8a59-b17ca43c3310", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: As we talk next Thursday, we'll talk some more about kind of what the growth rates look like for next year and kind of how that flows through the model. But there's no doubt that when we accelerate growth like this, it's hard for us to accelerate spending in the same rate and you never really kind of catch up for that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "9adf2a4b-405b-41d8-8a59-b17ca43c3310", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: It's one to be proud of.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "50db3a03-569c-4bf4-8e57-96e69ee0dcc1", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thank you so much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Alex Henderson", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "b0684b69-201a-417a-9018-8f7306ecc385", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Needham"}

section.text: Thanks, Alex.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "01c10f41-f914-45bf-9600-509160c5efa1", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Well, I guess I shouldn't ask you what everybody wants to know, which is what's your outlook for next year?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Silverstein", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "ec53f339-24cc-459d-adc5-9d9bd7a77972", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: You wait a couple of more days, Paul. Just a couple of more days.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "25b53b45-66dd-4540-bf4b-5605c96dda86", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: I'd ask you what everybody else is asking. So it sure doesn't sound like from the numbers that macro had much if any impact, but F5 last week did identify macro as a meaningful driver of a very disappointing outlook. Any thoughts you can share in terms of what you're seeing? Is it affecting one iota customer decisions as to your products and solutions? Any thoughts would be appreciated.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Silverstein", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "b64d3b65-2ced-42af-b6f3-fc40210a1d4d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: Look, I don't think Arista is a bellwether for macro. So we'll let the pundits on economists speak about that. But I think it's fair to say that data center spend has been very strong. And we're confident of our near-term strength, both in Cloud Titans, enterprise and campus. If there's a place that we see some softening at all geographically, I would point to Europe. They've had effect of the pandemic, the energy crisis, the war, the Brexit, it's just a whole lot of things going on there. But our numbers are small. And even there, I would say it's more enough to execute better. So overall, macro is not yet an issue for us. We'll keep a vigilant eye on it, but so far, so good.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "d0f61eb3-f4b7-4582-b663-4666288ef265", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Jayshree, just to be clear, you're not seeing elongated sales cycles, you're not seeing cutbacks, deferrals or cancellations to any appreciable extent in orders, especially from enterprise. I appreciate that you're small, but your enterprise is not nothing. It's a growing business. And correct me if I'm wrong, but historically, in times of economic duress, most organizations have declined to change vendors or put off changes in their infrastructure that would result in bringing a new vendor like yourself?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Silverstein", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "fc3b40bf-4bea-4628-adc7-711a108e3b88", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: Right. I don't think Arista is any more a new vendor. I think we are the best-of-breed vendor. And what we see, especially in networking, unlike any --
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "b771e804-bb56-4350-a1b9-6f9c5f893cb4", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Not incumbent.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Silverstein", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "ffe717d9-92cf-4ef5-86a5-2bb94fc18ef1", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: Yes, same point. We're not [Speech Overlap] That's right. I would say if anything, Paul, just to answer your question more directly, unlike server or storage, networking is a very, very strategic spend. There's a long qualification cycle that goes in. There's proof-of-concept lab. There's intense testing for scale. And we're all struggling with lead times. So switching vendors doesn't give you any particular advantage. And if you're looking for best-of-breed and best operational advantages, our customers would prefer to wait for us. So of course, we don't want to test their patience. We're going to do everything we can to execute. You're seeing that in our purchase commitment, but we've got to execute even better.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "6133de21-f990-4de0-abac-b85b3d003a6b", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: All right. Appreciate the response. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Silverstein", "section_number": 22, "uuid": "3ecda4a5-f863-4f08-95d1-74019ab21c6f", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 23, "uuid": "ec8739ac-61a0-4303-a47a-f0bfef946a48", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thanks, Paul.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Stine", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "c033413a-5c7b-47ed-83cc-2e72e91d1993", "speaker_title": "Director, Investor Relations at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thanks for taking the question. I wanted to get a little bit of help understanding how to think about the purchase order commitment. Just looking at the prior 10-Q filing, you had a 12-month commitment of like $2.9 billion, and you mentioned today that the overall commitment came down a little bit to $4.3 billion. But what I'm struggling with is if we just sort of try to back into implied revenue, it's well above what most of the Street is modeling for the next year. And there are a number of ways that we could think about it. You could either write off inventory, you could hold higher inventory levels or certainly you could have much higher revenue than we expect. I'm wondering if you could give us some advice on how to interpret these purchase order commitment? Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Simon Leopold", "section_number": 26, "uuid": "09b3ceff-7ada-4b7e-952b-daf463e41fe0", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Raymond James"}

section.text: Yes, Simon, I think obviously, the goal is to make the purchase commitments that we need to support the business, but it is multiyear, right? And we are thinking about this kind of longer term than just the year that's ahead, right? So that's why you're seeing the numbers kind of not match perfectly to whatever your revenue assumption is for just for 2023, right? So well, again, we'll talk about 2023 and the growth rate when we get to the Analyst Day. And then maybe you can ask this question again, and we'll try to provide some more guidance, but it really is about being multiyear, and some of these products are early stage products where we believe we can put [Technical Issues] there's a limited risk in terms of E&O and reserves and really you're tying up cash, but that's kind of the -- that's worth it in terms of being able to have the products and have the components in place when we need them.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "34bf7481-4a5e-446f-8532-4f44452e0098", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Simon Leopold", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "a09904e0-e7c5-46c9-8fbe-dedbfd0802c2", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Raymond James"}

section.text: Thanks, Simon.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Stine", "section_number": 29, "uuid": "341b14dc-539b-428f-8c5d-7637bf537052", "speaker_title": "Director, Investor Relations at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Great. Thanks. Ita and Jayshree, maybe if you could just comment on whether some of the upside that you're seeing from the Cloud Titans this year is due to kind of greater ability to serve them and get them more product than they wanted or if you're actually getting kind of stronger orders than expected? And just kind of on the deferred revenue, being recognized if there are projects that are kind of changing and timing that led to kind of the stronger-than-expected results? Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Meta Marshall", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "1f23ade1-f355-4673-a439-825cbdcb963c", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Thanks, Meta. So I think it's fair to say, as Anshul has often said that our relationship and partnership with the Cloud Titans continues to be strong and couldn't be better, especially with Microsoft and Meta, who we fully expect to be greater than 10% concentration. I wish we could ship them more. And I think if they were hearing this call, they would be saying, I wish you could ship us more too. So I don't think it is a case of shipping them more. I think it's a case of demand from them and a very strategic partnership at the engineering level, at the network design level, at the operational level, at the procurement level and actually Anshul, I'd like you to -- since you're dealing with this daily -- say some more.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "95db462a-9d49-4eee-a592-3f6ffbeab793", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Meta, the demand from these customers is just strong. Yes, there's some timing of revenue and deferred and so on, but that's not what's leading into their strength. The raw demand from these customers continue to be strong. They want to do more build-outs. If you look at how many data centers and regions they want to build out, it's very strong. you look at their DCI adds with 400-gig and 100-kilometer type of distances, building big regions, that's very, very strong. And they love our execution. As Jayshree mentioned, if we could give them more product, they would happily take it as well. So all in all, a phenomenal outcome compared to where we were two years ago, but very healthy cycle with our cloud customers.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Anshul Sadana", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "eedeb7f2-87ed-40b7-83df-ab097fb509a6", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: And Meta, on the deferred, I mean nothing for the year and out stage, right? If you look at it year-to-date, really the deferred is not a contributor at all at this point.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "49b7acbf-ecb8-418b-bb1b-f82093a4bc68", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Meta Marshall", "section_number": 35, "uuid": "8d5b0f6e-6c86-434b-875b-c5baf317fa67", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Stine", "section_number": 36, "uuid": "8fc094db-8898-41a1-a578-6c3897c400a1", "speaker_title": "Director, Investor Relations at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Good afternoon, everyone. Thanks for taking the question. I was hoping we could talk a little bit about just the broader supply and demand balance. I'm sure we'd all, you included, would love to know when this ends. But I'm curious how you're thinking about evolving from a supply perspective, when you think it maybe get directionally better, when it's really better? And then also curious how it's influencing the duration of visibility you're seeing from customers, that has gotten longer. Is it still getting longer? Is it starting to shrink? What are you seeing there? That's it for me. Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ben Bollin", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "a332e06e-958e-47f3-8f76-172131877c77", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cleveland Research"}

section.text: Okay. Hey, Ben, so you asked really two questions, what's the direction of our visibility? Is it getting longer? Generally, right now, because of our lead times, our visibility is approximately six months to a year. And we've now had that kind of visibility, particularly from our cloud providers. So directionally, it's not getting longer, but staying about the same is what I'd tell you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "1086d94c-ef42-4531-98ad-4eecb8c4a5cb", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: And then what are we seeing on supply chain and when is it going to get better? Gosh, one of the reasons that even Anshul and myself made such a concerted effort, we got Board approval for very large purchase commitments, multiyear despite a smaller revenue is exactly not to be in the spot we are, which is we wanted to get all our components. But sadly, we have almost all the components except a handful, and you can't build a system without the last few components. So we do have still shortages, as I said before, we expect this to go into 2023. And I think our long lead times will persist in the industry for networking, especially for the next several months and for 2023.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "1086d94c-ef42-4531-98ad-4eecb8c4a5cb", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: So we don't see a lot of relief in sight until we can get all the components. Being short of a few components still means we can't build the system. So expect us -- it's improving, but expect us to really only see improvement a year from now.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "1086d94c-ef42-4531-98ad-4eecb8c4a5cb", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thanks, Jayshree.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ben Bollin", "section_number": 40, "uuid": "9024ccbe-26a6-47a8-a7d7-16bdd3de25e2", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cleveland Research"}

section.text: Thanks, Ben.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Stine", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "14503a8e-2c1d-4496-b9e0-48859a9fca6d", "speaker_title": "Director, Investor Relations at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Hey. Thank you so much for taking the question. On the guide for the non-GAAP op income margin, so I think you did 42-ish percent this quarter. I know the guide talks about a nearly 200 basis point step down despite stable gross margins. So I'm just wondering if you can talk about where you see opportunity for incremental investment? And then if I could just sneak in one follow-up on the deferred revenue question. So it looked like deferred dipped about -- deferred revenue dipped about $92 million sequentially. I'm just wondering what's baked into the revenue outlook for 4Q from a deferred perspective? Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matt Niknam", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "d89b0422-8c0f-4e0d-9899-1d81b2683dfd", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Deutsche Bank"}

section.text: Yes. So on the deferred, the product deferred decline in Q3 is about $60 million. So there's a piece of it is just services, service contract timing and stuff in there. So really, the thing that's kind of directly linked to the revenue is about $60 million. For Q4 in the guide, we're assuming no deferred, right, and no deferred impact, right? So that's that question. And then the other question was the expenses and operating margin. I think look, we were flat pretty much on opex in Q3. Some of that is timing. That wasn't the original plan, obviously. So some of that will recover. And some of -- as we head into Q4, we'll see some sales, commissions and other things at the back end of the year, tend to be a little higher as well, right? So it's kind of a combination of maybe some timing and then just the normal kind of Q4 dynamics.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 44, "uuid": "39ed6f4f-55bf-4850-9860-b05730cce5d2", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thank you very much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matt Niknam", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "054a3a65-f05e-4c47-bd46-ad618f96e858", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Deutsche Bank"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "210c0b5a-0316-4ad9-b05e-3bc0cb037762", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thanks, Matt. Welcome to your first call.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "ae97bac5-28aa-48f7-93b6-fb53c56c066b", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thank you for taking my question. Jayshree, I think at a recent investor conference, you said that you think the industry could grow double-digit revenue, if I recall, you said you were connecting clouds of data or centers of data. So I want to understand your response to a previous question that if the supply chain improved next year, you would do well versus what that double-digit outlook that you had earlier. Is that what you're thinking? Can you help us understand?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Fahad Najam", "section_number": 49, "uuid": "5a5907ea-44db-414a-957d-67f8ce17991a", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Loop Capital"}

section.text: Yes, Fahad. I'll try. I think in terms of demand, we fully expect to grow double digits next year, and I hope for years to come unless there's some real macro issues. Specific to next year, again, we will guide specifically at Analyst Day. But I think if supply chain would be relieved, we would grow double digits. If supply chain continues to be constrained, we'll still grow double digits. So either way, [Technical Issues] well next year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "d3a75529-ee38-4f90-80a6-49fb944058e7", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: I have one follow-up.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Fahad Najam", "section_number": 51, "uuid": "6b05f128-f469-4168-a506-018c916c5544", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Loop Capital"}

section.text: It's a question of how well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 52, "uuid": "65ad874e-7b46-4b24-919a-c1e14324a703", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: What's the risk of your cloud customers having some level of inventory buildup? I understand that there is a significant constraint on the networking equipment, but there has been evidence of inventory mismatches in the server and storage space as some other Cloud Titans. And so what's the risk that there is going to be a mismatch etc.?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Fahad Najam", "section_number": 53, "uuid": "896a5879-b55b-4572-82dd-e5630f05bab4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Loop Capital"}

section.text: Very little, Fahad. I think it's important to understand that nobody has been in a position to have any kind of inventory on networking. Anshul, do you want to add to that?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "27e897b6-803f-4e0d-952c-f74306c9ebf4", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Yes. Fahad, our customers will consume everything we can ship. We are not worried about inventory build up any time soon.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Anshul Sadana", "section_number": 55, "uuid": "f3219afb-154c-4337-92f6-7887403a34cf", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Appreciate it. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Fahad Najam", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "8ab205df-3cec-42f8-9f5d-c8b577b5db91", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Loop Capital"}

section.text: Thanks, Fahad.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Stine", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "4eb438d4-d0a1-4243-9abb-423e97249dc2", "speaker_title": "Director, Investor Relations at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thanks, ladies and great quarter. I guess a couple of questions. Jayshree, you talked about your activity with the cloud guys and how -- that cloud guys do want diversity and suppliers. And of course, there's always timing and projects where you kind of run ahead or below where you probably should be just given the timing of projects. Do you get a sense right now on if you're punching above or below your weight kind of -- and I'm calling weight, whatever the cloud guys really think you should be at long term from a share standpoint?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ittai Kidron", "section_number": 59, "uuid": "bb5fbcef-2523-4291-92ed-fc999f3b58a5", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Oppenheimer"}

section.text: Hey, welcome back, Ittai. We haven't chatted in a long time. That's a really good question. You had to ask a tough one. I do think we're punching at our weight in terms of demand, even above our weight. In terms of actually supplying, maybe below our weight. But by the way, I'm only talking about the cloud guys, not myself. Anshul, do you want to add to that?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 60, "uuid": "7e7e25e1-483f-40d5-acd3-78a53bd965dc", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Well, I'm not here to refer boxing match. But in terms of supply, and overall demand, our customers like to diversify. I think most customers have already set their plans. We're not expecting any big dramatic changes from here on. And we talked about a couple of years now, that customers truly like our product. They like our execution. The partnership is healthy. We are not worried because of claims from any companies on how they'll be ahead and they will beat us and all of that. In the end, we've done really well. If someone takes a share in one of the roles, we take share in other roles, too. So as a result, because of the expansion in WAN and Edge and routing and other use cases, we've done well, and our expectation is we'll actually continue to do going forward as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Anshul Sadana", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "630b1a97-0e99-4995-9f75-fd7ec23dc254", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Got it. Okay. And maybe as a follow-up, Jayshree, I mean you did talk about the weakness in Europe, and it's obvious that there should be weakness over there. But your business over there is down on a year-over-year basis. And I guess I'm kind of wondering -- the traction and the share gains that you're having in the U.S., one would think that even in the current environment, if you're able to get share gains in Europe as well, you'd still be able to get growth out of there, maybe not 30%, 40%, but perhaps a 10%, 15%. So help me understand what -- maybe you could go later deeper into what's going on in Europe. And do you think that the current environment, maybe going back to your previous question, Paul's question, that in this environment perhaps customers are just less likely to consider a change, they'd just stick with what they've got and maybe that's a hindering element?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ittai Kidron", "section_number": 62, "uuid": "2c31dbee-ef89-4c1c-bc4d-735bcb6f8452", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Oppenheimer"}

section.text: So -- no, I don't -- I was answering the question, Ittai, more on, is there a recession. In a broad sense, if at all -- we are generally seeing very strong demand worldwide. If at all we are seeing some softness in weakness, it would be in parts of Europe because of all that they're going through. Specific to Arista, I see no reason we shouldn't be growing everywhere, including Europe. But our rate of growth in Europe may be slower for exactly the reasons you mentioned that their overall economy, if you look at the GDP and if you look at the top three countries, Germany, U.K. and France, none of them are really substantially investing. So I think because we have small numbers, we can do fine. We should be able to still grow double digits, but that is the only sign of recession we have so far seen.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 63, "uuid": "1220631f-e35a-4fd2-835a-b94066acde4d", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Good luck. Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ittai Kidron", "section_number": 64, "uuid": "defc9c50-f434-45a9-b24d-b0524b2e46b8", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Oppenheimer"}

section.text: By the way, just to correct you, we did -- we are growing year-over-year in Europe as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 65, "uuid": "32e0bb5d-13d6-45ab-9b2b-31ac46fb9c82", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Yes, the chip [Phonetic] numbers, Ittai, have a lot of cloud influence in them. So it depends when you strip that out, the kind of in-region business is growing.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 66, "uuid": "797269f8-00d0-4850-bfd5-e18344c0af6e", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Okay. Well maybe, Ita, on that point, did the U.S. grow? Can you tell us how much the U.S. grew without the Titans?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ittai Kidron", "section_number": 67, "uuid": "3940fee5-dab4-48da-8e09-e2ae8a403c3b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Oppenheimer"}

section.text: Off the top of my head, no. Yes.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 68, "uuid": "0dc4c49f-16a6-4e7c-81dc-b936564c9454", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: U.S., we do by year-end.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 69, "uuid": "431b09cb-8df3-45ca-a348-4db0c125c3a0", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Yes. We'll show you some stuff at year-end for sure on the verticals of the business.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 70, "uuid": "66953bc3-6a89-4294-a2a4-a461c7427935", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Appreciate it. Good luck. Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ittai Kidron", "section_number": 71, "uuid": "f6614d14-fe3e-407e-b67d-308e9d1a47ec", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Oppenheimer"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 72, "uuid": "1ce9e44e-d196-4003-805c-c8d0dc313597", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thanks, guys, for taking the question. I just want to go back to the margin performance. If I go back to 2019, I think your titan mix was relatively similar to where we are today, maybe a little bit less. But your gross margins were almost 300 -- your product gross margins were almost 300 basis points higher. So can we kind of disaggregate that delta is how much of that is from expedited freight, supply chain versus maybe somewhat structurally lower margins with some of the new titans and/or Microsoft and Meta? And then on opex, just a quick question. Growth has been 15% to 20% sort of on a year-over-year basis. Is that kind of how we should think about the business as we progress over a couple of year cycle? Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Vogt", "section_number": 74, "uuid": "c17c44dd-8bce-40ac-b97d-273ab6648191", "speaker_title": "Analyst at UBS"}

section.text: Yes, I think on the gross margin piece, I mean, there is more cloud mix in the business, I think, than we've seen --
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 75, "uuid": "288c67f0-ab2a-478a-9d8e-e618c64d70cd", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Than we've ever seen. This is the highest mix we've had.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 76, "uuid": "42b248c8-31f2-4c71-98bd-4877f287b5f2", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: But we also have -- remember, don't forget the expediting fees and stuff we've talked about the 200 to 300 basis points. I mean that is still there. I think that will be there for a while, certainly in our Q4 guide. So I think it's a combination of those 2, right? When you think back in that time period, you could run the business for costs, right? And we were optimizing costs in every way. Today, we're kind of hamstrung because of supply. So it's inefficient right now, to be honest, right, particularly with these decommits. So we need to get out of that, and then we can kind of start to drive for some improvements on the gross margin side as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 77, "uuid": "3aa039b9-e200-4f27-a5ab-ec467d07018b", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: I think on the opex side, if you look back historically, we've probably been in the 20%, 22% growth type range on opex except in times of disruption, right? So I mean, that's probably not a bad way to think about it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 77, "uuid": "3aa039b9-e200-4f27-a5ab-ec467d07018b", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Got it. And maybe just a quick follow-up. So it sounds like your structural margins on the titans are relatively unchanged over the last, call it, two to three years outside of the expedite fee and supply chain. Is that a fair characterization on the product side?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Vogt", "section_number": 78, "uuid": "587a1eb1-0170-4777-bb18-6074072784ba", "speaker_title": "Analyst at UBS"}

section.text: I think it depends on the product mix to some degree, right? I mean, you've got -- there's more -- you'd have to do more disaggregation to really get to what's happening there, right? But there's -- the product mix is a part of that as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 79, "uuid": "659336ae-8dc3-4b44-ad43-9d2cf1b8c42f", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Okay. Thanks, guys.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Vogt", "section_number": 80, "uuid": "620ca34b-75c5-4757-afbc-567c23764523", "speaker_title": "Analyst at UBS"}

section.text: Thanks for taking my question. Congrats on the good quarter. I guess the question is on the Cloud Titan side, and on a broader level of vertical, we're seeing an increased focus on profitability from the cloud company. And I'm just wondering, as they start to focus perhaps more of the resources on their own core competencies, could you see a lot of these cloud companies started to shift from building their own solution on the networking side versus starting to buy them more often? I would love to understand, A, from your existing customer base, are you seeing an expansion of engagement with them beyond what you've traditionally done? And then, B, more importantly, are you seeing newer customers come to you that want to start buying for you rather than building it organically themselves?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Amit Daryanani", "section_number": 82, "uuid": "90bcf919-914c-43e2-875b-a68eb2193244", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore"}

section.text: Okay. Thank you, Amit. I'll take it in two parts. The Cloud Titans have always had a combination of build and buy. So I don't think that's changing. They continue to look at whether it's SONiC or FBOSS, working closely with us -- but in some layers, they are absolutely sourcing their own products and technology. At the same time, I think the Cloud Titans have to run very mission-critical networks, and they recognize the value in the partnership at an engineering level to not build themselves, but really co-develop with us. So these, I would say, are not built or buy. They're really codeveloped partnerships where they get the best of both. And despite all of their focus on costs, believe me, they're getting their best of both because they're getting great cost for us without making the direct investment themselves, and it really is a unique partnership.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 83, "uuid": "366860a2-c434-4303-9144-cc5449d05749", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Anshul, you want to say some more to that?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 83, "uuid": "366860a2-c434-4303-9144-cc5449d05749", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Sure. Amit, in general, these cloud companies keep exploring every possible way to go faster. There's a misunderstanding in the entire -- But it's on the Wall Street side of things, sometimes people have said, hey, people want to find something that's cheaper because they can save money. The reality, they have to look at their total overall business impact. And if they can go faster and get a competitive advantage, that's a huge benefit to them. So most of these companies do not build their own products or stack just a bit cheaper. They build it because there's some secret sauce. There's some IP, there's some integration. That's what you're seeing with the co-development we do with Meta and Microsoft, whether it's on the FBOSS, SONiC side or some of the hardware we developed as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Anshul Sadana", "section_number": 84, "uuid": "cf98d401-6462-4f8e-b055-15e20bd9a1be", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: The other titans explore the same use cases are similar themes with us on an ongoing basis. So these are not new discussions to us, and I think we'll continue to execute well. Clearly, the majority of the business continues to come from our top two customers. We are happy with that. The others are engaged as told previously, but those are long running projects, but then they'd get to a decision point and actually impact, you have to wait several years and we'll get there. But there's nothing that's changed in the industry. People are in generally happy with the way status quo has been maintained with a little bit of let's explore other options in working with companies like us where possible.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Anshul Sadana", "section_number": 84, "uuid": "cf98d401-6462-4f8e-b055-15e20bd9a1be", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thanks, Amit. Operator, we can take the next question.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Stine", "section_number": 85, "uuid": "e42237d5-c188-4d45-bdec-1b656801402a", "speaker_title": "Director, Investor Relations at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Yes. Thanks for taking the question. Congratulations as well on the quarter. I wanted to ask a little bit more of a technical question. As we think about 400 gig and you think about the traction you're seeing with your Cloud Titans as well as some of the specialty cloud guys, I'm just curious if you could level set us on where you think we're at in terms of the 400-gig cycle? And on that topic as well, any updated thoughts on this idea of the AI Fabric networks representing an incremental adjacent growth driver for your business at the Cloud Titans? Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Aaron Rakers", "section_number": 87, "uuid": "6bc0d77f-fea0-47ec-993c-5bd3940a91e7", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Unquestionably. I think while majority of the enterprise is still on 10 and 40, we are seeing more and more combinations of 100 and 400 gig, not only in the Cloud Titans, but also in the rest of the customer base. Just to level set on the numbers, you may recall that we had 70 or so customers in 2020. We doubled to 300 into 2021. And if I had to guess, I would say we double again in 2022 in terms of 400-gig customers. But the important thing to remember here is that they are not just 400. There really are a permutation and combination of multiple speeds, multiple use cases. And together, they are an important contributor, but it's never an isolation 100. Some of them are uplinks, some of them are native connections. Some of them, as Anshul alluded, are DCI routing solutions. So our market share in this combination of 100, 400 and in some cases, 200 is number one for good reason because they really have to work together with the right software and right management.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 88, "uuid": "4eb36808-9a70-4498-857d-60e31a6828da", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: The AI spine cluster is emerging as a new use case. It's still early days, and we've talked about it some. We'll talk about it more at the Analyst Day, but more use case emergence for applications that really push the speed and latency and performance and predictable bandwidth of 400 gig is going to add additional fuel to our 400-gig demand.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 88, "uuid": "4eb36808-9a70-4498-857d-60e31a6828da", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thanks, Aaron.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Stine", "section_number": 89, "uuid": "e1bfa1f1-5450-4197-8f1d-6ec0790b0e0b", "speaker_title": "Director, Investor Relations at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thank you. Jayshree, Ita, I noticed in your press release that you made a comment to new market expansion. Could you elaborate a little bit like what is that? Or is that going to be a focus for the event on Thursday? Because I assume it's not just continual strength of where you're seeing or maybe it is. But if you can give any expansion on that? Because I know in the past, currently, you've seen a lot of expansion in the campus growth, but I saw the new market expansion literally, word for word, and I got to think there was some purpose behind that. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jim Suva", "section_number": 91, "uuid": "b2f50db1-c8a2-4da6-a0bd-4c3c598fca86", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup"}

section.text: Maybe you read more into my quote than I meant. At the end of the day, Arista is viewed as a data center company. But if you look at the diversified portfolio, we're trying to say we're entering many more new markets like routing, like campus and even subsets of the market like securing our solutions better with encryption, with better visibility and observability. And indeed, we'll talk more about new market expansion in a couple of days. So undoubtedly, we're moving from becoming a pure data center company to many more markets that center the data in different locations.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 92, "uuid": "ace0ba9c-8e90-470a-b650-f615af03078b", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thank you so much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jim Suva", "section_number": 93, "uuid": "7d6de828-46c6-43c8-9d1d-020db49df4a8", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup"}

section.text: Thank you, Jim.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 94, "uuid": "a1630036-7a3b-4d58-9003-95572110230c", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Yes. Thank you. Thanks for squeezing me in here. I guess it's a similar question to the last one, but Jayshree, I just wanted to understand, as we look at your growth with cloud customers, how should we think about sort of that growth relative to sort of how much of that growth is coming from the additional use cases you're addressing beyond traditional switching. So for example, like DCI or routing, how much of that is probably contributing to the strong growth you're seeing with cloud customers? As we think about sort of the next couple of years, how should we think about the -- given the visibility you have in terms of designs, how is that sort of momentum progressing from here on? And just a quick follow-up there. So outside of Facebook and Meta as we think about the engagement with other cloud companies, is that on some of the new use cases? Or is that traditional switching in leaf and spine?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Samik Chatterjee", "section_number": 96, "uuid": "eab00251-3ded-44aa-9956-3714aa7fd067", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JPMorgan"}

section.text: First, I think it's super important to understand that even though it's leaf and spine, Samik, these data centers, whether they be building them at a regional level or a mega scale level, the leaf and spine is really going to expand and explode as the Cloud Titans expand their presence. So that growth -- that organic growth that we began our journey with them will continue. And we will depend on that growth. In addition to that, as Anshul said, we will have new use cases on the WAN, the regional, the DCI and especially AI spine, particularly with the Cloud Titans. It may expand to those new use cases and it may also expand to other specialty cloud providers. But I would say we would be looking for sources of growth in both areas, expansion of the existing data centers into new locations and more scale as well as new use cases.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 97, "uuid": "58e5afb0-6df5-47c8-95e8-6a20fb06aac7", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Samik Chatterjee", "section_number": 98, "uuid": "dd3589fc-c9e2-4a0e-8321-2d632cf8e5a5", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JPMorgan"}

section.text: Six of one and half a dozen of the other.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 99, "uuid": "44e4d918-7a74-4b32-902a-9f707c3fca59", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Thanks, Samik.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Stine", "section_number": 100, "uuid": "8050dae3-fc2b-4f37-aef0-9e585ed1040e", "speaker_title": "Director, Investor Relations at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Hi, guys. Thanks very much. I guess I wanted to go back to the question of the Cloud Titan customers potentially building inventory. And I guess, on an earlier question, Anshul, you were pretty dismissive of that idea. I guess I'm just wondering what additional detail you might kind of have that supports that idea. And if I look at your business, you've been growing product sales 55%, 67% year-on-year, the last couple of quarters, it's pretty outstanding growth. And given the mix shift in the company, I would guess that the Cloud Titans customers have been growing 70% or 80% year-on-year, right? So I know you guys are building your own inventories. Many companies are building their own inventory in the supply chain environment. So I do think it is an important question and I guess I'm wondering exactly how you know customers aren't building inventory in your stuff? Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "George Notter", "section_number": 102, "uuid": "5a20d69a-c382-4646-8f0e-b2b71f8dc355", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Jefferies"}

section.text: George, that is a good question. I get asked that internally daily because we have to worry about what's going on in the other side, our customers buffering. I would say the best sign is the number of phone calls I get or Jayshree gets or others in the company get on when the hell are you shipping? So these customers are still roughly hand-to-mouth. There are a few places where they can still calibrate for the computer to come up and so on. But in most cases, customers are desperate, the deployment teams are waiting for the gear to show up, and they light it up as quickly as possible.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Anshul Sadana", "section_number": 103, "uuid": "f332152c-5c4d-46ea-a5f5-bebd36815307", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: You have to realize where we came from. But since the start of COVID, the world has been constrained. And that constrain over such a long period, generally means people can't execute the project time lines, and they're still short. At some point, this will recover but nowhere close to that in today's time. So I think it will take a long time, maybe I'll say if supply recovers by the end of '23, I think that's when customers will feel comfortable, and they will eventually have an opportunity to buffer up, but not yet, not there today.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Anshul Sadana", "section_number": 103, "uuid": "f332152c-5c4d-46ea-a5f5-bebd36815307", "speaker_title": "Chief Operating Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Okay. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "George Notter", "section_number": 104, "uuid": "60f2147b-beed-436a-bbd6-68e12c67e739", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Jefferies"}

section.text: Thanks, George.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Stine", "section_number": 105, "uuid": "9a5bc70e-8d25-4d26-b54a-8b73eab94503", "speaker_title": "Director, Investor Relations at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Hi. Thank you. I wanted to go to gross margins. I think Ita, you've made two references on this call regarding just the trajectory of margins. I think you said that we're probably not going to see an improvement in gross margins for at least a year from now. And then the other comment you made regarding the 200 to 300 basis points, I think you said it's going to be there a while. So does that imply that we should be modeling gross margins at least through maybe the first half of 2023 a little bit more in line to last couple of quarters? That's the first question.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Sami Badri", "section_number": 107, "uuid": "e364f688-f15f-42b4-a724-6a2c147b03a4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: Second question is if you were to give us an idea on how many ports or how many switches with 400-gig ports shift to 2022, could you give us kind of like a percentage of total shipments and maybe what that would look like in 2023?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Sami Badri", "section_number": 107, "uuid": "e364f688-f15f-42b4-a724-6a2c147b03a4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: Yes. Just on the gross margin, I think given where we are today, I think it's not a bad idea to model that gross margin as being kind of constrained until we get out from under the constraint, honestly. I think that's a very real kind of cost that we're carrying, and it's not clear yet exactly when that starts to improve. So yes, I think it's not a bad idea to hold it there until we're able to kind of show real demonstrable improvements and more predictability, I guess, on these decommitted parts.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 108, "uuid": "5c8ae757-1765-41d6-b0fa-e06c606ab4fa", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Yes. And to answer your question, we -- I don't have exact numbers on 400 gig, but if I had to guess even though we're gaining customers, most of them are as uplink. So the number of ports is still small. I would say our penetration is well under 10%, maybe even 5%. That's just a good guess.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 109, "uuid": "7627e439-c14f-45bc-9681-711cf3ab0b5d", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: And then thank you for answering gross margin and that piece. But when we go into 2023, are you seeing almost like a sharp increase in that from sub-10% to obviously much higher than that or not quite yet?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Sami Badri", "section_number": 110, "uuid": "0babeb4c-5bd6-40ee-a0be-9646b029c98f", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: No, no. If we go into '23, the way to think of this is people are still migrating from 10 gig and 10 and 40 to 100 will still be the largest migration. As a result of that migration, you will see more deployment of 400 gig. So 400 gig will still be small. Maybe it will go from 5% to 10%.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 111, "uuid": "33fedf26-3097-4a06-9ff6-79b731d4cd8b", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Perfect. Thank you very much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Sami Badri", "section_number": 112, "uuid": "40539df9-85ca-4110-91ba-1ba9d96044cf", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Stine", "section_number": 113, "uuid": "c07654a6-b236-4bf0-8028-c6b522998839", "speaker_title": "Director, Investor Relations at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Hey, ladies. Nice quarter. Well, it's a metric, Ita, I know you don't really want to emphasize as much as others do in your space. You still have visibility here and confidence in that visibility. Maybe asking in a different way than others. As supply chain here starts to normalize, how are you guys thinking about how long that backlog actually takes to turn back to a more normal level? Is it four, six, kind of eight quarters, that's currently in your thought process for next year? Are you seeing any change in cancellation rates? And then just lastly, what's going on with that services deferred revenue as in aggregate, we were down about $92 million and product was only -- was down $63 million. So trying to understand why services is being impacted here?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "James Fish", "section_number": 115, "uuid": "35247857-6822-40fe-a1b8-1cfc1140b16d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Piper Sandler"}

section.text: Yes. We start with the services piece. I mean it's just all about the timing of the of the service agreements, right? If you think about what deferred venue is, if I sign a contract on day one, it's a two-year, three-year contract, you're going to have the maximum amount of deferred revenue you can have. And then when it comes towards the renewal of that contract, you're going to have the least amount of deferred revenue that you could have from a services perspective, right? So it's purely on timing on the services side, right? The lumpier thing is obviously on the product, but the services is truly just the mechanics of how the services contracts flow, right?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 116, "uuid": "c32b59ef-4f79-43dd-8c72-b027a1f18a1b", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: And then I guess on the cancellations, etc., I mean, we have not seen any change in the business. I think we're to Anshul's point, I mean, we're still seeing customers very intensely focused on getting products at this point. I'm not going to try to age out the backlog, it's kind of a -- we're not quite there ready to do that just given some of the uncertainties on supply and so on.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 116, "uuid": "c32b59ef-4f79-43dd-8c72-b027a1f18a1b", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: And I think as lead times improve, we expect customer visibility to shrink. But right now, we're working hard on that lead time improvement. So we're a year away from that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 117, "uuid": "2fe8e777-d260-49b1-b0c0-1fc42b3eeb3a", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Operator, we have time for one more question.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Stine", "section_number": 118, "uuid": "0f0dc335-d9f6-43e0-8fa8-5d38b7700510", "speaker_title": "Director, Investor Relations at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Hey. Thanks for squeezing me in, and Happy Halloween, everybody.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Tom Blakey", "section_number": 120, "uuid": "5f16c8c9-6a27-4a3e-9bf6-0b2a6d13cacd", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KeyBanc"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 121, "uuid": "2a71ded1-6fc2-4cc3-bf64-60f3d8f51218", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Looking at your -- curious about the cadence of the Cloud Titan revenue. It seems like a big uptick here in the second half, if I'm characterizing that correctly from kind of the mid- to high 30s to get to that 45% for the year, you need to imply kind of over half. And if I do that simple arithmetic, it implies that maybe the cumulative revenue of service providers, specialty service providers, financial enterprise will be kind of flattening out in the second half. So just maybe comment on is my characterization correct.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Tom Blakey", "section_number": 122, "uuid": "93b17bf7-bf71-44fb-b0e7-bd1bdd676e11", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KeyBanc"}

section.text: And there as a follow-up, are we relying a little bit more on one of those particular Cloud Titans more than the other? And about a correlation to actual capex spend comment would be helpful, too. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Tom Blakey", "section_number": 122, "uuid": "93b17bf7-bf71-44fb-b0e7-bd1bdd676e11", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KeyBanc"}

section.text: Yes. I mean I think as you look at the year, I mean, obviously, we've been ramping revenues and ramping shipments. So we have been ramping kind of with cloud as well, right? And cloud has grown faster. It started off from a lower base, obviously. So it did need to recover, if you like, it was at 30%, which is pretty much the lowest we've seen it last year, and we -- so it's definitely recovered from there. I think on the rest of the business, the demand is there. The demand has certainly exceeded our expectations when we came into the year. But given the shipment constraints, etc., it's kind of a bit of -- we've been trying to stick to the FIFO first in, first out as much as we can. And -- so that has been more constrained. I think we'll expect to see that kind of start to improve, hopefully, here as we head into next year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ita Brennan", "section_number": 123, "uuid": "0a263420-5ed9-43de-a7f1-9a9fd49a360b", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Meta versus Microsoft maybe into the second half of the year?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Tom Blakey", "section_number": 124, "uuid": "676e5759-a452-48f2-adec-3be2dac4c477", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KeyBanc"}

section.text: Yes, we'll have to wait till the year-end for that, I think.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jayshree V. Ullal", "section_number": 125, "uuid": "ea006292-18d3-4d52-b473-e937ea234976", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at Arista Networks"}

section.text: Okay. Thanks, everybody.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Tom Blakey", "section_number": 126, "uuid": "26999c51-be0d-4ecb-bc19-39040a79bfe0", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KeyBanc"}

section.text: This concludes the Arista Networks Third Quarter 2022 Earnings Call. We have posted a presentation, which provides additional information on our results, which you can access on the Investors section of our website. Thank you for joining us today, and thank you for your interest in Arista.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Liz Stine", "section_number": 127, "uuid": "f8ee8dc6-cc96-43e4-b080-93e54c3ba910", "speaker_title": "Director, Investor Relations at Arista Networks"}

title: Q&A for ANET (Arista Networks) on 10/31/22 4:30 PM ET
